H0.text: Igneous is a rock type that forms from the burial and compression of organism remains by mud.

H1.text: Sedimentary is the type of rock that forms when the remains of organisms are buried by mud and compressed.

H2.text: Magma is a rock type that forms from organisms dying, their remains becoming buried by mud, and eventually being compressed into rock.

H3.text: Metamorphic is a rock type that forms from the burial and compression of organism remains by mud.

A4.text: Sedimentary rocks are types of rock formed by the cementation of sediments that have been accumulated or deposited at Earth's surface.

A5.text: Unlike most igneous and metamorphic rocks, sedimentary rocks form at temperatures and pressures that do not destroy fossil remnants.

A6.text: Sedimentary rocks are only a thin veneer over a crust consisting mainly of igneous and metamorphic rocks.

A7.text: Chemical sedimentary rock forms when mineral constituents in solution become supersaturated and inorganically precipitate.

A8.text: In these wetlands, the process of coalification began when dead plant matter was protected from oxidation, usually by mud or acidic water, and was converted into peat.

A9.text: Coalification began when dead plant matter was protected from oxidation, usually by mud or acidic water, and was converted into peat.

A10.text: The grains of most limestones are embedded in a matrix of carbonate mud.

A11.text: Organic sedimentary rocks are important deposits formed from the accumulation of biological detritus, and form coal and oil shale deposits, and are typically found within basins of clastic sedimentary rocks.

A12.text: Sedimentation results in the formation of depositional landforms and the rocks that constitute the sedimentary record.

A13.text: Sedimentation is the deposition of sediments.

A14.text: Carbonate rocks are a class of sedimentary rocks composed primarily of carbonate minerals.
